'

ganza which the Banistorniers are
to give during the week of March
17, at the Lyceum Theatre, has at
last leaked out, due to a voluntary
relaxation of vigilance on the part
of the Club. The spirit of the- production is said to be accurately embodied in the fanciful title, ."Have
You Bean to Lima?"
• In extenuation thereof, the informatidn is proffered that the scene
of the play is laid in Peru. It will
differ from the usual elaborate fantasia, for it will boast a plot that
is easily discernible to the naked
eye. In spite of the fact that Flo
Ziegfeld is said to have exhausted
the field, the Club has accomplished
the supposedly impossible, for the
comedy will contain a number of
absolutely original features: The
committee is outspoken in saying
that the HOpkins' production will
surpass any others seen lately in
Baltimore in this respect. The features will not be divulged before
the time of the production, so • a
pleasant surprise is awaiting the
people who view the show during
the week of March 17.
The music will be amply cared
for by J. J. Sherr, '25, who has
been appointed to write the tunes
for all lyrics used. The words are
snappy, having been contributed by
both undergraduate and graduate
students. "Tin-pan Alley" has produced nothing to beat them, is the
claim made by Club members.
The production will be staged by
last year's men, Hamburger and
Smallwood, who will leave for New
York tomorrow to consult with
Mario Badillo, '23, .of the Physioc
Studios, who will lend his expert
advice to the Barnstormers' show's
costuming and staging. The dancing and singing will have their special professional coaches, and Mr.
Walter Swindell, the Club's head
coach, will supervise the entire production. The testing of the fifty
candidates will start next week.
With the artistic end of the work
so well cared for, the Business
Staff is having more than its share
of difficulties. At present preliminary details are being attended to
but the nights for the various benefits have not been arranged as yet,
and this is where the'chief difficulty
lies. The only possible way • in
which to assure the Club a full attendance each night, hence financial
success, is to give to various local
organizations benefit nights, and
negotiations are under way with
several charities. As soon as a majority of these are completed successfully the last obstacle in the
way of a banner -production will
have been removed, and the Club
will be ready for the Johns Hopkins production, "Have You Bean
to Lima?" to go on the stage.

NOTICE
All undergraduates are to
meet at the Barn at five
o'clock this afternoon to see
the team off.
Be There!

LOYOLA COLLEGE ROMPS
ON HOPKINS FRESHMAN
TEAM AT HOMEWOOD
Yearlings Powerless Against Slashing
Attack of More Experienced
Eleven

_ Displaying both _ defensive and
offensive strength with, plenty of
punch,-the Loyola College football
team triumphed over - the Johns
Hopkins Freshmen, 20-0. Loyola's
superior weight was too much for
its -much lighter 'opponents, and
time and again big•chunks of yardage were gaMed through the line.
The defeat was decisive, for the
freshmen played raggedly throughout the whole game, except for
times when Brian made good gains
through the line, or Brown did
some good tackling. The game was
a short affair, the quarters lasting
only eight minutes.
In the first quarter Loyola kicked
to Hopkins' forty-yard line and
Brian brought it to midfield. Hopkins tried to gain through the line,
but after several unsuccessful attempts, kicked to Loyola's 35-yard
line. With the ball in their possession for the first time, Loyola completed three - first downs, through
the line, end-running and two very
good passes. But the ball finally
landed on Hopkins' 10-yard line,
when the whistle blew for the first
quarter.
In the second quarter Loyola
took the ball from the 10-yard line
and with a good forward made a
touchdown. Hopkins then kicked
to Loyola's 25-yard line. Loyola
fumbled on their 40-yard line and
it was Hopkins' ball. At this point
Gough threw a forward, but it was
uncovered and O'Brennan, of Loyola, intercepted it, to run 50 yards
for the second touchdown. Hopkins then kicked again to Loyola,
and the ball was placed on their 45yard line. Grinsfelder here intercepted a forward, but it was too
late, as the half was over.
In the second half Grinsfelder
kicked off to Loyola on their 20yard line, but the ball was run back

'

ganza which the Banistorniers are
to give during the week of March
17, at the Lyceum Theatre, has at
last leaked out, due to a voluntary
relaxation of vigilance on the part
of the Club. The spirit of the- production is said to be accurately embodied in the fanciful title, ."Have
You Bean to Lima?"
• In extenuation thereof, the informatidn is proffered that the scene
of the play is laid in Peru. It will
differ from the usual elaborate fantasia, for it will boast a plot that
is easily discernible to the naked
eye. In spite of the fact that Flo
Ziegfeld is said to have exhausted
the field, the Club has accomplished
the supposedly impossible, for the
comedy will contain a number of
absolutely original features: The
committee is outspoken in saying
that the HOpkins' production will
surpass any others seen lately in
Baltimore in this respect. The features will not be divulged before
the time of the production, so • a
pleasant surprise is awaiting the
people who view the show during
the week of March 17.
The music will be amply cared
for by J. J. Sherr, '25, who has
been appointed to write the tunes
for all lyrics used. The words are
snappy, having been contributed by
both undergraduate and graduate
students. "Tin-pan Alley" has produced nothing to beat them, is the
claim made by Club members.
The production will be staged by
last year's men, Hamburger and
Smallwood, who will leave for New
York tomorrow to consult with
Mario Badillo, '23, .of the Physioc
Studios, who will lend his expert
advice to the Barnstormers' show's
costuming and staging. The dancing and singing will have their special professional coaches, and Mr.
Walter Swindell, the Club's head
coach, will supervise the entire production. The testing of the fifty
candidates will start next week.
With the artistic end of the work
so well cared for, the Business
Staff is having more than its share
of difficulties. At present preliminary details are being attended to
but the nights for the various benefits have not been arranged as yet,
and this is where the'chief difficulty
lies. The only possible way • in
which to assure the Club a full attendance each night, hence financial
success, is to give to various local
organizations benefit nights, and
negotiations are under way with
several charities. As soon as a majority of these are completed successfully the last obstacle in the
way of a banner -production will
have been removed, and the Club
will be ready for the Johns Hopkins production, "Have You Bean
to Lima?" to go on the stage.

meet at the Barn at five
o'clock this afternoon to see
the team off.

LOYOLA COLLEGE ROMPS
ON HOPKINS FRESHMAN
TEAM AT HOMEWOOD
Yearlings Powerless Against Slashing
Attack of More Experienced
Eleven

_ Displaying both _ defensive and
offensive strength with, plenty of
punch,-the Loyola College football
team triumphed over - the Johns
Hopkins Freshmen, 20-0. Loyola's
superior weight was too much for
its -much lighter 'opponents, and
time and again big•chunks of yardage were gaMed through the line.
The defeat was decisive, for the
freshmen played raggedly throughout the whole game, except for
times when Brian made good gains
through the line, or Brown did
some good tackling. The game was
a short affair, the quarters lasting
only eight minutes.
In the first quarter Loyola kicked
to Hopkins' forty-yard line and
Brian brought it to midfield. Hopkins tried to gain through the line,
but after several unsuccessful attempts, kicked to Loyola's 35-yard
line. With the ball in their possession for the first time, Loyola completed three - first downs, through
the line, end-running and two very
good passes. But the ball finally
landed on Hopkins' 10-yard line,
when the whistle blew for the first
quarter.
In the second quarter Loyola
took the ball from the 10-yard line
and with a good forward made a
touchdown. Hopkins then kicked
to Loyola's 25-yard line. Loyola
fumbled on their 40-yard line and
it was Hopkins' ball. At this point
Gough threw a forward, but it was
uncovered and O'Brennan, of Loyola, intercepted it, to run 50 yards
for the second touchdown. Hopkins then kicked again to Loyola,
and the ball was placed on their 45yard line. Grinsfelder here intercepted a forward, but it was too
late, as the half was over.
In the second half Grinsfelder
kicked off to Loyola on their 20yard line, but the ball was run back
